awd_titl_txt: Business-Higher Education Forum (BHEF) Proposal to Implement & Evaluate Models for Business Engagement to Increase Undergraduate STEM Student Persistence

por.por_cntn:
In 2014, with major support from the National Science Foundation (NSF), the Business-Higher Education Forum (BHEF) launched a five-year project to advance knowledge in a largely unexplored area of four-year undergraduate STEM education: evidence-based models for strategic and sustainable engagement by business with higher education to increase the persistence of STEM students, particularly veterans, women, and underrepresented minorities. The project identified the transfer of students from two-year to four-year institutions as a key juncture that, if addressed, could significantly increase both the diversity and overall STEM degree attainment at the baccalaureate level.

To achieve these outcomes, BHEF built the Undergraduate STEM Interventions with Industry (USI2) Consortium as a learning community for the project sites. With NORC at the University of Chicago serving as the project evaluator, five individual BHEF-member sites worked with business to implement evidence-based interventions--high impact practices (HIPs)--to increase STEM student persistence, transfer, and completion. This project helped determine whether business engagement in partnerships using HIPs increases community college student transfer to baccalaureate STEM programs and success in STEM majors.

To advance these partnerships and ensure alignment of knowledge and skills with employers' needs, BHEF developed the Partnership Implementation Process, an eight-step process to move partnerships from the initial workforce analysis and competency map, to the design of new academic programs and student pathways, to changed employer hiring practices. BHEF played an intermediary role, including coordination and oversight, that was essential for success. The project demonstrated that the methodology is replicable and scalable across a range of geographic settings, types of institutions, economic sectors, and disciplinary foci in a variety of pathways to college success and career readiness.

Using this process, the partnerships created exemplary programs in areas including data science, cybersecurity, water science, and engineering that incorporated synergistic, industry-engaged HIPs, including summer bridge programs, undergraduate research, internships, first-year experiences, capstone projects, academic learning communities, and cooperative education. In total, 1,414 students were engaged through these programs, over 40 percent of whom were underrepresented minorities and over 25 percent of whom were women. NORC's evaluation found that these programs were effective in supporting college transfer students in pursuing STEM degrees and careers. The success of the grant resulted in a BHEF-NSF reskilling workshop convening 150 leaders to explore strategies to build the STEM-capable workforce to meet employers' highest-demand needs, as well as how to scale the process in 12 regions across the country through the Business Roundtable's Workforce Partnership Initiative supported by a $1.2 million foundation grant to BHEF.

BHEF and the consortium produced approximately 70 products to share learning and insights from the grant with a broader audience, including case studies, whitepapers, presentations, journal articles, websites, blog posts, and other publications. In particular, BHEF's 2020 publication, Building Bridges to Success: Regional Business-Higher Education Partnerships to Grow and Diversify the STEM Workforce, available at www.bhef.com provides further information on the outcomes of this grant.

 


Last Modified: 03/17/2020
Modified by: Janet L Chen
